an3.27:1.1: “These three individuals are found in the world.
an3.27:1.3: There is an individual you should be disgusted by, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.
an3.27:1.4: There is an individual you should regard with equanimity, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.
an3.27:1.5: There is an individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend.
an3.27:1.6: Who is the individual you should be disgusted by, and not associate with, accompany, or attend?
an3.27:1.7: It’s an individual who is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, festering, and depraved.
an3.27:1.8: You should be disgusted by such an individual, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.
an3.27:1.10: Even if you don’t follow the example of such an individual, you still get a bad reputation:
an3.27:1.11: ‘That individual has bad friends, companions, and associates.’
an3.27:1.12: They’re like a snake that’s been living in a pile of dung. Even if it doesn’t bite, it’ll still rub off on you.
an3.27:1.13: In the same way, even if you don’t follow the example of such an individual, you still get a bad reputation:
an3.27:1.14: ‘That individual has bad friends, companions, and associates.’
an3.27:1.15: That’s why you should be disgusted by such an individual, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.
an3.27:2.1: Who is the individual you should regard with equanimity, and not associate with, accompany, or attend?
an3.27:2.2: It’s an individual who is irritable and bad-tempered.
an3.27:2.3: Even when lightly criticized they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and they display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
an3.27:2.4: They’re like a festering sore, which, when you hit it with a stick or a stone, discharges even more.
an3.27:2.5: In the same way, someone is irritable and bad-tempered.
an3.27:2.6: They’re like a firebrand of pale-moon ebony, which, when you hit it with a stick or a stone, sizzles and crackles even more.
an3.27:2.7: In the same way, someone is irritable and bad-tempered.
an3.27:2.8: They’re like a sewer, which, when you stir it with a stick or a stone, stinks even more.
an3.27:2.9: In the same way, an individual is irritable and bad-tempered.
an3.27:2.10: Even when lightly criticized they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and they display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
an3.27:2.11: You should regard such an individual with equanimity, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.
an3.27:2.13: Thinking, ‘They might abuse or insult me, or do me harm.’
an3.27:2.14: That’s why you should regard such an individual with equanimity, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.
an3.27:3.1: Who is the individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend?
an3.27:3.2: It’s an individual who is ethical, of good character.
an3.27:3.3: You should associate with, accompany, and attend such an individual.
an3.27:3.5: Even if you don’t follow the example of such an individual, you still get a good reputation:
an3.27:3.6: ‘That individual has good friends, companions, and associates.’
an3.27:3.7: That’s why you should associate with, accompany, and attend such an individual.
an3.27:3.8: These are the three individuals found in the world.
an3.27:4.1: A man who associates with an inferior goes downhill,
an3.27:4.2: but associating with an equal, you’ll never decline;
an3.27:4.3: following the best, you’ll quickly rise up,
an3.27:4.4: so you should keep company <j>with people better than you.”
